questions.question: Define the term homologous series.
questions.answer: A family of organic compounds with the same functional group and general formula, with each successive member differing by CH₂.

questions.question: State what is meant by a functional group.
questions.answer: An atom or group of atoms responsible for the characteristic reactions of a compound.

questions.question: Explain why shorter-chain alkanes have lower boiling points.
questions.answer: They have weaker London dispersion forces due to fewer electrons and a smaller surface area.

questions.question: State the conditions required for the catalytic cracking of alkanes.
questions.answer: High temperature and a zeolite catalyst.

questions.question: Explain why cracking is an important process in the petroleum industry.
questions.answer: It converts long-chain hydrocarbons into more useful shorter-chain alkanes and alkenes used for fuels and chemical feedstock.

questions.question: State the meaning of the term structural isomer.
questions.answer: Compounds with the same molecular formula but different structural formulae.

questions.question: Explain why E–Z isomerism occurs in alkenes.
questions.answer: It occurs because there is restricted rotation around the C=C double bond and each carbon has two different groups attached.

questions.question: State the reagent and condition needed for the hydration of ethene to produce ethanol.
questions.answer: Steam (H₂O(g)) and a phosphoric acid catalyst at high temperature and pressure.

questions.question: Explain why addition reactions occur in alkenes.
questions.answer: The C=C bond has a region of high electron density which attracts electrophiles.

questions.question: State the type of reaction when bromine reacts with an alkene.
Explain why bromine water is decolourised when added to an alkene.
questions.answer: The alkene reacts with bromine in an electrophilic addition reaction, breaking the Br–Br bond and forming a dibromoalkane.
